The Catalytic Materials and Coating Symposium will be devoted to the application of new uncommon materials in catalysis, use of uncommon catalysts (cellular blocks, foam materials, coatings for chemical reactor vessels, etc.) in catalytic processes and the use of different types of waste to produce catalysts. The Ceramic Materials Symposium will cover the follow- ing topics: Ceramic Components in Batteries and Fuel Cells; Ceramic Sensors; Ceramic Actuators; Ceramics for use in Heat Engine Components; and Lifetime Prediction for the Performance of Ceramic Functional and Structural Components. Interested readers should contact the organization secretariat or the Eastern and Western chairpersons listed in the Calendar. Calendar of Forthcoming Events New Items For full Calendar see Appl. Information on planned events should be sent well in advance (preferably 6 months or more) to Prof. J.R.H. Ross, University of Limerick, Plassey Technological Park, Limerick, Ireland, fax. (+353-61) 411400 or to Applied Catalysis, Desk Editorial Office, PO. Box 330, 1000 AH Amsterdam, Netherlands, fax. (+31-20) 5862459. Book Review The Chemistry and Technology of Petroleum (2nd. Edition), by J.G. Speight, Marcel Dekker, New York, NY, 1991, ISBN 0-8247-8481-2, $175.00/$201.25. This book covers nearly all the aspects of the petroleum related industry and gathers in a unique, well documented work a large amount of information normally only available from very widespread sources. For non-specialists, the petroleum industry is often hardly understandable because of the difficulty of acquiring its large, diversified vocabulary. In this respect the first chapter provides a valuable guide with extensive and precise definitions of the terminology related with the constituents of crude oil and manufactured materials. The last two chapters also contribute to a clear comprehension of the definition and properties of the products generated by the refining industry and to the derived chemicals directly obtained from petroleum. Ten of the 21 chapters deal with the origin, formation, recovery, composition and characterization of crude oil. The precise and complete information given in this part of the text is abundantly illustrated and documented with numerical data. These aspects of petroleum related knowledge are of fundamental importance for a clear apprehension of refining; in this respect, they are extremely valuable for catalysis specialists. The first part introduces the description of refining processes. The essential aspects of the chemistry of refining are collected in a distinct chapter, followed by a description of the basic operations of refining: distillation, cracking, hydroprocessing, final cleaning and treatment processes. Once more, illustrations are abundant, clear and precise. For such an extensive text, bibliography is a challenge. The author's choice consisted in the selection of a limited number of pertinent references. A wider selection would have been profitable for some topics. Petroleum engineers, chemists, refiners and, of course, catalysis specialists should incontestably consider this text as a reference for a global understanding of the present, major energy resource in the world. Villeurbanne M. BREYSSE applied catalysis A: General Volume 102 No. 2 - 31 August 1993 APCATA 9380239M 0926-860X(93)80239-M 10.1016/0926-860X(93)80239-M Calendar of forthcoming events
